lines.content: This is a project template for a greenfield Java project. It's named after the Java mascot _Duke_. Given below are instructions on how to use it.
Prerequisites: JDK 17, update Intellij to the most recent version.
1. Open Intellij (if you are not in the welcome screen, click `File` > `Close Project` to close the existing project first)
1. Open the project into Intellij as follows:
1. Select the project directory, and click `OK`.
1. If there are any further prompts, accept the defaults.
1. Configure the project to use **JDK 17** (not other versions) as explained in [here](https://www.jetbrains.com/help/idea/sdk.html#set-up-jdk).
In the same dialog, set the **Project language level** field to the `SDK default` option.

1. After that, locate the `src/main/java/Bingy.java` file, right-click it, and choose `Run Bingy.main()` (if the code editor is showing compile errors, try restarting the IDE). If the setup is correct, you should see something like the below as the output:

**Warning:** Keep the `src\main\java` folder as the root folder for Java files (i.e., don't rename those folders or move Java files to another folder outside of this folder path), as this is the default location some tools (e.g., Gradle) expect to find Java files.

* Represents the main entry point for the Bingy chatbot application.
* It coordinates user input, parsing, task management, and UI.
private static TaskManager taskManager = new TaskManager(100);
private static final Storage storage = new Storage("tasks.txt");
private final Ui ui = new Ui();
* Loads tasks from storage, greets the user, and continuously reads input
* Handles user input and executes corresponding command.
* @param input raw String user input when user presses enter.
* @throws EmptyTaskException if the command is missing a required task description.
private void handleInput(String input) throws EmptyTaskException {
// Preserve the user's command word for a clearer error message

ui.sendMessage(" Give me a task number. Numbers are characters like 1 or 2. Hope that helps!");

ui.sendMessage(String.format("Removing tasks on your list doesn't make it go away. Removed:\n    %s", t));
if (cmd.arg1 == null || cmd.arg1.trim().isEmpty()) throw new EmptyTaskException("todo");
* Displays goodbye message to user after "bye" input
* Saves the current list of tasks to persistent storage.
* If saving fails, displays an error message to the user.
super("Please add a deadline you want your task done by\n Example: \"deadline return book /by [YYYY-MM-DD]\"");
super("Please add start and end time for your event\n Example: \"event project meeting /from Mon 2pm /to 4pm\"");
super("Cannot search nothing: Please add a keyword you want to search");
super(String.format("You can't add an empty %s item. Try again.", taskType));

* Represents a deadline task with a description and a due date.
* A {@link Deadline} is a concrete subclass of {@link bingy.tasks.Task}
* that associates a textual description with a {@link java.time.LocalDate}
* Creates a new {@link Deadline} task with the specified description and due date.
* @param description the description of the deadline task.
* @param deadline the {@link java.time.LocalDate} by which the task is due.
* Returns a string representation of this deadline suitable for storage.
* The due date is formatted in ISO-8601 ({@code yyyy-MM-dd}) format to ensure
* consistency when reloading tasks from persistent storage.
* @return the storage-ready string representation of this deadline.
* Represents an event task with a description, start time, and end time.
* An {@link Events} task is a concrete subclass of {@link bingy.tasks.Task}
* that includes two string fields to represent the start and end times.
* Creates a new {@link Events} task with the given description, start, and end times.
* @param description the description of the event.
* @param start the start time of the event.
* @param end the end time of the event.
public Events(String description, String start, String end) {
* Represents an abstract task in the Bingy application.
* Encapsulates common fields and behavior for all task types,
* including a description, completion status, and formatted string output.
* Concrete subclasses such as {@link ToDo}, {@link Deadline}, and {@link Events}
* Creates a new task with the given description.
* Tasks are initialized as not done.
* @param description the textual description of the task.
* Marks this task as completed by setting its status to done.
* Marks this task as not completed by resetting its status to undone.
* Returns the textual description of this task.
* Returns a status icon representing whether the task is done.
* "X" if completed, otherwise a blank space.
* @return a string representing the task's completion status.
* Returns a type tag that identifies the concrete subclass of this task.
* Implemented by subclasses such as {@link ToDo}, {@link Deadline}, and {@link Events}.
* @return the type tag string for this task.
* Returns a formatted string representation of this task,
* including its type tag, status icon, and description.
* @return a human-readable string representing the task.
* A concrete subclass that extends from {@link bingy.tasks.Task}
* Represents the most basic form of the Task class with only the description field.
* Initializes a {@link ToDo} task with the given description.
* @param description the textual description of the to-do item.
* Provides methods to parse both user commands and stored task lines.
* Used at runtime to convert raw user input into a structured {@link Parser.ParsedCommand}
* for execution, and also to reconstruct tasks from their serialized form in storage.
* A structured representation of a parsed command.
* Instances are produced by {@link #parseUserCommand(String)} for runtime commands
* and by {@link #parseStorageLine(String)} for persisted task lines.
* All supported command kinds recognized by the parser.
LIST, TODO, DEADLINE, EVENT, MARK, UNMARK, DELETE, BYE, UNKNOWN, FIND
* Parsed command metadata and arguments. Fields may be {@code null} when
* intentionally left unspecified so that the caller (e.g., Bingy) can
* surface a more specific error message instead of a generic UNKNOWN.
* Creates a command with only a {@link Type} and no arguments.
* Useful for simple commands like LIST or BYE.
* Creates a command with a primary string argument (e.g., index or description).
* @param arg1 primary argument (may be {@code null} when missing)
* Creates a DEADLINE command with description and due date.
* @param deadline ISO-8601 date for the deadline (may be {@code null})
public ParsedCommand(Type type, String arg1, LocalDate deadline) {
* Creates a command with up to three string arguments (e.g., EVENT: desc, start, end).
public ParsedCommand(Type type, String arg1, String arg2, String arg3) {
* Creates a command that carries a completion flag (used when parsing storage lines).
* @param isDone whether the item was marked completed
* Creates a command with a completion flag and a primary argument.
* @param isDone completion status parsed from storage
public ParsedCommand(Type type, boolean isDone, String arg1) {
* Creates a DEADLINE command from storage with completion flag and due date.
* @param isDone completion status parsed from storage
public ParsedCommand(Type type, boolean isDone, String arg1, LocalDate deadline) {
* Creates an EVENT command from storage with completion flag.
* @param isDone completion status parsed from storage
public ParsedCommand(Type type, boolean isDone, String arg1, String arg2, String arg3) {
* Parses a raw user input line into a {@link ParsedCommand}.
* The parser avoids throwing user-facing exceptions; instead, it returns specific
* command types with {@code null} fields when arguments are missing so the caller
* can provide contextual error messages. Unknown commands are returned as
* @return a structured {@link ParsedCommand} describing the intent and arguments
// description present, but missing or empty /by portion
// description and /by present; try ISO parse (yyyy-MM-dd)
// Gracefully return EVENT with nulls so BingyBot can throw specific errors
return new ParsedCommand(ParsedCommand.Type.EVENT, (String) null, (String) null, (String) null);
return new ParsedCommand(ParsedCommand.Type.EVENT, (String) null, (String) null, (String) null);
// No /from provided; treat everything as description only
// Have /from but no /to yet → missing end time
// Normalize empty strings to null for cleaner checks downstream
return new ParsedCommand(ParsedCommand.Type.EVENT, description, start, end);
char typeChar = line.charAt(1); // T, D, or E
return new ParsedCommand(ParsedCommand.Type.EVENT, isDone, desc, start, end);
* Handles persistence of tasks to and from the {@code data/} directory.
* Ensures the data folder exists, and reads/writes a plain-text file that
* represents tasks line-by-line. Deadlines are stored with ISO-8601 dates.
* Create a new instance that takes in a file name and reads and writes from the data directory.
* @param fileName the name of the file used for read and write.
throw new RuntimeException("Could not create data directory", e);
* Writes all tasks to the storage file in a line-based format.
* {@link bingy.tasks.Deadline} entries are serialized using their
* {@code toStorageString()} (ISO-8601 date) while other tasks use
* @param list the tasks to persist; order is preserved.
* @throws IOException if an I/O error occurs while writing.
public void save(ArrayList<Task> list) throws IOException {
* Loads tasks from the storage file, if present.
* Each line is parsed back into a concrete task using
* {@link bingy.util.Parser#parseStorageLine(String)}. Missing files are treated as empty.
* @return a list containing all tasks found in the file (maybe empty).
* @throws IOException if an I/O error occurs while reading.
* TaskManager encapsulates the list of tasks and provides operations to mutate it.
private final List<Task> tasks = new ArrayList<>();

* Creates and adds a new {@link bingy.tasks.Deadline} to the task list.
* @param description the description of the deadline task.
* @param deadline the {@link java.time.LocalDate} by which the task is due.
* @return the {@link bingy.tasks.Deadline} that was created and added.
public Deadline addDeadline(String description, LocalDate deadline) {

* @param end the end time of the event.
* @return the {@link bingy.tasks.Events} that was created and added.
public Events addEvents(String description, String start, String end) {
Events task = new Events(description, start, end);
* Returns an unmodifiable view of the current tasks.
* Returns the number of tasks currently in the list.

* Handles all user interface interactions for the Bingy application.
* Responsible for displaying messages, task lists, greetings, and status updates
* in a consistent format. This class does not contain business logic; it simply
* renders information passed from other components such as {@link bingy.util.TaskManager}
* and task types like {@link bingy.tasks.Task}, {@link bingy.tasks.ToDo},
* Prints the ASCII logo and a greeting banner when the application starts.
System.out.println(" WHAT caan't I doooOoo for yoou?");
* Prints a message wrapped by horizontal separator lines for consistent formatting.
* @param message the text to display to the user.
* Prints a farewell banner when the application exits.
System.out.println(LINE + "\n bbbbYEE. hope to scareee you again soooooOOon! \n" + LINE);
* Displays list of matched tasks and enumerates matching tasks.
* Displays all tasks in the given list, numbered from 1.
* @param tasks the list of {@link bingy.tasks.Task} to display.
System.out.println("Here's the list of chores you will NOT complete MUAHAHAH");
